children.text: Wellyboots recognises that many staff enjoy networking with friends and family via social media. However, we have to balance this against our duty to maintain the confidentiality of children and parents attending Wellyboots, as well as ensuring that our good reputation is upheld. Staff must remember that they are ambassadors for Wellyboots both within and outside of working hours and are expected to conduct themselves accordingly when using social media sites.
This policy covers (but is not limited to) social media platforms such as:
Twitter
Facebook
YouTube
Tumblr
Personal blogs and websites
Comments posted on third party blogs or websites
Online forums
Instagram
Online gaming
Social media rules

Wellyboots uses WhatsApp as a general messenger service this allows all who wish to participate to share events, information and pics of the aforementioned (with the parental signature of permission to do so).
When using social media sites, staff must not:
Post anything that could damage our reputation.
Post anything that could offend other members of staff, parents or children using Wellyboots.
Publish any photographs or materials that could identify the children or our setting.
Accept invitations from parents or children to connect via social media (eg friend requests on Facebook or a gaming invitation) unless they already know the parent in a private capacity.

Discuss with parents any issues relating to their child or our setting. Instead invite the parent to raise the issue when they are next at Wellyboots, or to contact the Manager if the matter is more urgent.

Any member of staff who posts content or comments that breach confidentiality or which could harm the reputation of wellyboots or other staff members, or who publishes photographs of the setting or children, will face disciplinary action in line with our Staff Disciplinary policy.
General cautions for using social media
When using social media in any context it is wise to bear in mind the following points:
No information published via the internet is ever totally secure; if you don’t want the information to become public, do not post it online.
Once an image or information is in the public domain, it is potentially there forever – Google never forgets!
